item.title: South Korea Begins Naval Drills With the U.S.
item.description: President Park Geun-hye also calls on South Korea’s military leaders to punish the North if it further raises tensions.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Assad Is Sworn In for Third 7-year Term in Syria
item.description: During a closely scripted ceremony, President Bashar al-Assad swore on the Quran to respect the Constitution and look after the Syrian people.
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria reviewed an honor guard at the presidential palace in Damascus on Wednesday.

item.title: Pakistani Forces Attack Militant Bases in Remote North
item.description: At least 35 people were killed, the military said, hours after locals reported that an American drone strike in the same area killed 20 others.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Greek Fugitive Is Arrested in Athens Shootout
item.description: Nikos Maziotis, the self-professed leader of Revolutionary Struggle, resisted an inspection by the police, leading to an exchange of fire in a busy shopping district.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Nikos Maziotis at the maximum security Korydallos prison in Athens in 2011.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Note to Cadres: Hands Off the Black Audi and Chauffeur
item.description: As part of its drive against corruption and waste, the Chinese Communist Party said it would stop allowing dedicated official vehicles for all but the highest-ranking government staff.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Two Moscow Construction Workers Arrested Over Fatal Subway Crash
item.description: Investigators said that the workers had improperly installed an underground switch, leading to the derailment Tuesday that killed 22 passengers.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Flowers were left outside the entrance to a metro station in Moscow on Wednesday.

item.title: Court Finds Netherlands Responsible for Srebrenica Deaths
item.description: The Dutch court ruled that United Nations peacekeepers from the Netherlands failed to protect Bosnian Muslims during the 1995 massacre.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Caliph Has No Clothes
item.description: The rhetoric of the ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi amounts to little more than a jihadist fantasy.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By CHASE F. ROBINSON

item.title: China’s G.D.P. Expands, but Businesses Aren’t Feeling the Effect
item.description: Independent surveys of companies across the nation show that in sector after sector, sales and confidence are still deteriorating.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Forbes Conrad for The New York Times
item.media:description: People shopping at the wet market in Baiyun District, Guangzhou, on Wednesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Chinese-Language Lesson Ripped From the Headlines
item.description: Accompanying a Chinese-language lesson in Global Times was a cartoon showing a young TV news anchor about to be yanked off the stage by a hook, an unmistakable reference to Rui Chenggang, who was detained last week.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In Sudan, the Janjaweed Rides Again
item.description: Sudan’s ailing president has made a militia notorious for its atrocities into his personal army.
item.dc:creator: By AHMED HUSSAIN ADAM

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Invasion of Britain
item.description: All the kids coming to learn English in the summer are the reason Europe will endure.
item.dc:creator: By BEPPE SEVERGNINI

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Japan’s Break With Peace
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s dabbling in militarism is a threat to the stability of the entire region.
item.dc:creator: By NORIHIRO KATO

item.title: Israel Tells 100,000 Gazans to Flee; Both Sides Press Attacks
item.description: The Israeli military warned residents of the Gaza Strip on Wednesday to evacuate their homes ahead of more airstrikes, as Israel intercepted four rockets over Tel Aviv after bombing the homes of several Hamas officials.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Palestinians on Wednesday sat near the house of Mahmoud al-Zahar, a senior Hamas leader, after it was destroyed by an Israeli airstrike.

item.title: Israel Intercepts Rockets Over Tel Aviv
item.description: The rockets were fired as Israel hit the homes of several Hamas leaders overnight and warned 100,000 residents of Gaza to evacuate their homes by 8 a.m.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Palestinians on Wednesday stood near the house of Mahmoud al-Zahar, a senior Hamas leader, after it was destroyed by an Israeli airstrike.

item.title: Storm Leaves Trail of Destruction in Philippines
item.description: Officials said Wednesday that Typhoon Rammasun had killed several people but that the toll could have been higher if residents had not evacuated.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Lens Blog: Fishing in South India’s Troubled Waters
item.description: A regional conflict between traditional South Indian fisherman and the government of Sri Lanka is exposing deep environmental problems in the globalized economy.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN BLAUSTEIN
item.media:description: Koodankulam, Tamil Nadu. Fishermen protest near the proposed nuclear plant on World Fisheries Day.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Book Editor Says His Firing Was Linked to Tiananmen Gathering
item.description: Li Xuewen said he was dismissed from his job as a senior editor at a state-owned publisher as retribution for attending an event marking the anniversary of the June 4 crackdown.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Tibetan Activist on Her Latest House Arrest
item.description: In a phone interview, the Tibetan writer Tsering Woeser said that she assumed that Chinese security forces knew about her invitation to dinner by the United States Embassy when they barred her from leaving home.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Tsering Woeser in Inner Mongolia last month.

item.title: World Briefing: Philippines: A Deadly Typhoon
item.description: A powerful storm cut through the Philippines on Wednesday morning, killing at least one person and sending more than 150,000 people into shelters, disaster response officials said.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: In Call, Obama and Merkel Discuss ‘Cooperation’ on Intelligence
item.description: The White House said President Obama and Chancellor Angela Merkel discussed “ways to improve cooperation” after revelations of American spying activities jarred relations between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: World Briefing: Somalia: Sweep Aims at Militants
item.description: More than 200 suspects were arrested Tuesday in a security sweep aimed at stemming a wave of militant attacks in Somalia’s capital, a senior police official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Cambodia: Protest Turns Violent
item.description: Opposition demonstrators disarmed Cambodian security forces and beat them with batons and flagpoles on Tuesday, two weeks before the anniversary of a disputed general election.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Chinese Oil Rig Near Vietnam to Be Moved
item.description: A Chinese energy company said it would move a giant oil rig from disputed waters off the coast of Vietnam, two months after its arrival raised tensions.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Witnesses Testify Against Ex-Blackwater Colleagues in Case of 2007 Iraq Killings
item.description: In a federal courtroom in Washington, former Blackwater employees confronted their one-time colleagues standing trial for a shooting that left 17 Iraqis dead.
item.dc:creator: By MATT APUZZO
